results.title: Tribute to a bad man
results.creator_credit: Robert Wise, Sam Zimbalist and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: James Cagney stars as a no-nonsense land baron Jeremy Rodock, who plays by his own rules, his own sense of justice and his own code of honour. Young cowhand Steve Miller (Don Dubbins) learns the hard way what it mean’s to incur Rodock’s wrath when he falls in love with the beautiful Jocasta Constantine (Irene Papas), whom Rodock considers his property. Through the example of the even-tempered Miller, however, Rodock rediscovers his own essential humanity. This excellent adaptation of Jack Schaefer’s short story features early screen appearances by Vic Morrow and Lee Van Cleef.

results.title: Tribal people of Mindanao
results.creator_credit: Dennis Azzarella, Wolper Productions and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: This film looks at two tribes in the Philippines - one which has been resettled in a mountain valley, and the Tasaday, who have only just been discovered. The valley tribe is seen briefly, in a slash and burn agricultural setting. The Tasaday tribe, however, is still living a stone age existence. Narrated by Leslie Nielsen.

results.title: Triangle Island
results.creator_credit: Ray Harper, Tom Radford, Michael Scott, Anne Wheeler and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Forty miles northwest of Vancouver Island lies Triangle Island, an ecological reserve and home of close to one million birds. Bristol Foster, head of the British Columbia Ecological Reserves Program, guides us across the island through colonies of birds and sea lions. He stresses the need of preserving the ecological balance for the survival of future generations.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ray Harper, Tom Radford, Michael Scott, Anne Wheeler and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Triangle and anchor: Chelsea porcelain from the Williamsburg Collection
results.creator_credit: Gene Bjerke and Arthur L. Smith
results.brief_description: Traces the history of porcelain from China in the 9th century to Chelsea, England in the mid-eighteenth century. Discusses the various factory marks used on Chelsea porcelain and shows the development from simple white tableware to elaborately coloured and gilded dishes and figurines

results.title: Trial run
results.creator_credit: Melanie Read, Don Reynolds, New Zealand Film Commission and CTM Cinema and Television
results.brief_description: When she is offered an assignment photographing rare penguins, Rosemary, a middle-distance runner, leaves her family for six months to live in a cottage on the coast. Her son, also a keen runner, devises a training schedule for her on his computer and, along with his sister, visits her frequently for running sessions. Despite regular contact with family and friends, Rosemary is disturbed by unexplained attacks on her house, strange noises in the night, and intimidation from her misogynist neighbour and his dog. Even when the attacks escalate she insists on staying in the cottage until one night, alone and terrified, she is forced to run for her life. This feminist approach to the psychological thriller portrays its female protagonists as strong, independent and quite capable of looking after themselves while effectively utilising lighting, music and shooting styles usually associated with this genre to build suspense and tension.

results.title: Trial on the Road
results.brief_description: Lazarev is a German soldier who is captured by a young and raw Russian partisan. Lazarev is himself Russian and had enlisted in the German forces when they had over-run his land. Lazarev’s initial test of loyalty comes when he is able to trick some German offices and overpower them. Finally his trial of loyalty is put to one supreme test when he is asked to lead a group attempting to hijack a train.

images.caption: Trial on the Road (Alexei Gherman) still

results.title: Trial at Nuremberg. Facing judgement.
results.brief_description: This video documents the trial of 21 German war criminals at Nuremberg over a period of 217 days from November 1945-1946. This film describes the events at the end of the Second World war leading up to the trials. “Facing judgement” is a Movietone newsreel following the trial of Adolph Eichmann in Israel in 1961 for crimes committed during the Second World War.

results.title: Trevor Island
results.brief_description:
The latest adventure from Australia’s ATOM award winning supercat. Trevor’s family move to a tropical island and decide to set up an airport and car park. A sedate lifestyle, however, is not Trevor’s trademark. As usual, Trevor meets this challenge in his own way.
Voices by Richard Healy, Jane Lewis, Danny Nash, David Crosbie and John Taylor.

results.title: Trepang
results.brief_description:
Every wet season between the early 1600s and 1906, when the Australian government outlawed the practice, Macassan sailors from Indonesia would sail to Arnhem Land to collect and harvest the sea slug or ‘trepang’. The sailors would pay local Yolngu people in return for permission to harvest the trepang and a culture of interchange and trade was born between these two communities.

In 1994, Darwin artist Andrish Saint-Clare began working with the Yolngu people from Elcho Island and with Macassan performers from Sulawesi to embark on a memory-retrieval process which could lead to the staging of stories of this important period in history. The final work, ‘Trepang’, evolved into a cross-cultural, indigenous opera that was performed on Elcho Island and Sulawesi and then again for a wider audience in Darwin.

At the Australian centre for the Moving Image, the video artwork Trepang has its genesis both in this early period of cultural contact and collision, and in these recent theatrical performances.

In consultation with Saint-Clare, ACMI has created a small screen-and-mirror assemblage in which a storm of images - echoes of knowledge, trouble and memory - and reflections all buffet together as if the past is rumbling in from just over the horizon. A sequence of six images plays in random patterns across the screen, occasionally bursting forth as one flash of unified meaning, and at other times flickering in different, staggered combinations. The visual fragments appear like the debris of history washed up on the shore and the participation of the viewer creates a sense that these fragments - part history, part song, part dance, part dream - are like navigation markers that help the people from the present calculate their orientation with reference to the past.

Andrish Saint-Clare has worked extensively in indigenous and intercultural performance. He worked for many years as a tutor and composer with the National Aboriginal and Islander Dance Association, and recently staged a new theatrical work ‘Fire Fire Burning Bright’ as part of the Melbourne Festival in 2002.

results.title: Trends in children's books
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: An interview with Albert Ullin, winner of the 1986 Dromkeen Medal award for his contribution to children’s literature. He also talks about changes that have occurred in Australian children’s literature over the past twenty- five years
